text: Several studies have pointed to a link between immune and endocrine systems , including a regulatory function of GH on monocyte activation .

The present study demonstrates that human THP-1 promonocytic cells , engineered by gene transfer to constitutively produce human growth hormone ( hGH ) , secreted depressed amounts of <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in response to challenge by LPS .

text: The effect of GH appears to occur in an autocrine fashion , since the inhibitory effect on <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> secretion by constitutive GH production could be abolished in the presence of anti-hGH mAb .

text: The GH - induced inhibitory effect was also observed using normal human monocytes and monocyte - derived macrophages .

Inhibition of <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production by THP-1-hGH - transfected cells cultured in the presence of LPS is dependent on a selective pathway , since no inhibition of <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production was observed when cells were cultured in the presence of PMA .

text: Inhibition of <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> secretion by LPS - stimulated THP-1-hGH cells was associated with a decrease in nuclear translocation of nuclear factor-kappaB .

text: The capacity of GH to inhibit LPS - induced <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production by monocytes without altering other pathways leading to <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production may be of potential relevance in septic shock , since GH is available for clinical use .
